response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "Beginning 1/1/2026, this measure requires pharmacy technicians to be registered with and obtain a certificate of registration from the Board of Pharmacy. [CHUNK 132] It imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians. [CHUNK 133] The measure specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns and has an effective date of December 31, 2050. [CHUNK 133] [CHUNK 128]",
  "appropriations": "",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "",
  "agency_impact": "To align the measure with the Board’s current Hawaii Administrative Rules (HAR), the Board requested amendments which were adopted by the committee. [CHUNK 14] [CHUNK 138] The committee deleted language that would have required the supervision of a registered pharmacy technician by a registered pharmacist to be \"direct\". [CHUNK 139] The committee also deleted language from the definition of \"supervision\" that would have required the responsible registered pharmacist to be physically present to oversee a registered pharmacy technician or pharmacy technician performing certain acts. [CHUNK 140]",
  "economic_impact": "The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK 72] Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or the rules adopted pursuant to this chapter shall be fined no less than $100.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK 126]",
  "policy_impact": "The measure adds new definitions to chapter 461, Hawaii Revised Statutes, for \"Auxiliary pharmacy personnel\", \"Registered pharmacy technician\", and \"Supervision\". [CHUNK 78] It amends the powers and duties of the board to include issuing certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [CHUNK 86] Disciplinary actions under section 461-21 are expanded to allow the board to deny, revoke, or suspend any registration. [CHUNK 119]",
  "revenue_sources": "Revenue will be generated from a registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [CHUNK 72] The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK 72] Each certificate of registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, upon which a new registration shall be required. [CHUNK 71]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "Beginning January 1, 2026, the State will collect revenue from a biennial registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [CHUNK 70] [CHUNK 71] The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK 72] Each certificate of registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year. [CHUNK 71] This will require the board to issue certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians and renew permits to operate pharmacies. [CHUNK 86] The board may also fine, suspend, or revoke any registration or permit for any cause prescribed by this chapter. [CHUNK 88] Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined no less than $100.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK 126] The supervising registered pharmacist shall be responsible for the actions of the registered pharmacy technician. [CHUNK 74] A registered pharmacy technician may perform filling, packaging, manipulative, repetitive, or other nondiscretionary tasks, only while assisting and while under the supervision and control of a registered pharmacist. [CHUNK 103] Section 26H-6, Hawaii Revised Statutes, which concerns the repeal of professional and occupational licensing acts, shall not apply to this Act. [CHUNK 127] This Act shall take effect on December 31, 2050. [CHUNK 128]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "Operating revenue will increase from the collection of biennial registration fees. [CHUNK 71] The registration fee for a pharmacy technician is $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK 72] Additional, non-recurring revenue may be generated from fines for violations, which range from $100.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) to $1,000.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK 126]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "Ongoing fiscal implications will include recurring biennial revenue from the pharmacy technician registration fee of $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK 72] The requirement for biennial renewal of the certificate of registration will ensure a continuous revenue stream. [CHUNK 71] The committee inserted an effective date of December 31, 2050, to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK 140]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This measure has been amended to include a new registration fee for pharmacy technicians of $20.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) and fines for violations ranging from $100.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt) to $1,000.00 (HB72_SD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK 72] [CHUNK 126] Following recommendations from the Board of Pharmacy, language that would have required supervision to be \"direct\" or for the pharmacist to be \"physically present\" has been deleted. [CHUNK 139] [CHUNK 140] The measure now statutorily defines \"Auxiliary pharmacy personnel\", \"Registered pharmacy technician\", and \"Supervision\". [CHUNK 78] A new effective date of December 31, 2050, has been inserted to encourage further discussion. [CHUNK 140]"
}

and Rae Matsumoto, Dean Daniel K. Inouye College of Pharmacy University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo HB 72 HD2 – RELATING TO PHARMACY Chair San Buenaventura, Vice Chair Aquino, and Members of the Committee: Thank you for the opportunity to submit testimony on HB 72 HD2. The University of Hawaiʻi at

testimony on HB 72 HD2. The University of Hawaiʻi at Hilo (UH Hilo) supports HB 72 HD2, which will require the registration of pharmacy technicians through the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. Pharmacy technicians are career professionals working under the supervision of a pharmacist, and have an essential role

the supervision of a pharmacist, and have an essential role in the daily operation of pharmacies. Hawaiʻi is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians. Legislation to address this oversight is important for supporting public health and safety by ensuring that these essential health

public health and safety by ensuring that these essential health care workers have the appropriate background and supervision, can receive timely communications and updates regarding relevant practice and regulation changes that impact their work, and facilitate access to training opportunities as the scope of practice of pharmacy technicians expands nationwide.

as the scope of practice of pharmacy technicians expands nationwide. We would like to emphasize that pharmacy technicians are professionals and represent a distinct category from pharmacy interns who are students in training to become future pharmacists. As career professionals in the health care workforce, pharmacy technicians perform functions under

in the health care workforce, pharmacy technicians perform functions under the supervision of pharmacists and may include roles such as dispensing medications, processing insurance claims, preparing sterile compounds such as intravenous (IV) solutions and chemotherapy, and with additional certifications, administering vaccines to patients. As career professionals in the health care

vaccines to patients. As career professionals in the health care workforce, the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility and trust afforded by the public. Thank you for the opportunity to testify in support of HB 72 HD2. e- A¢$ 2‘ D 0”‘ q“

B. 72, H.D. 2, RELATING TO PHARMACY Chair Yamashita and Members of the Committee: My name is James Skizewski, Executive Officer of the Board of Pharmacy (Board). The Board voted unanimously to support this measure but requests

The Board voted unanimously to support this measure but requests amendments. The purpose of this bill beginning 1/1/2026 is to: (1) require pharmacy technicians to be registered; (2) impose a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians; and (3) specify that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible

technicians; and (3) specify that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. The Board supports this measure’s intent to regulate pharmacy technicians. The Board recently formed a permitted interaction group to look at the best methods to regulate pharmacy technicians for quality

at the best methods to regulate pharmacy technicians for quality and general assurance. The group noted the need to recognize national certifications provided by entities such as the Pharmacy Technician Certification Board, while still acknowledging the presence of local technicians who have received extensive on the job training. The Board

who have received extensive on the job training. The Board agreed that a registration for all technicians may be a prudent initial step regarding the regulation of pharmacy technicians. An expansion to the scope of practice to technicians that are nationally certified should also be recognized. The expansion should include

nationally certified should also be recognized. The expansion should include allowances such as those provided in Act 104 of the 2024 legislative session. “direct” be removed from page 4, line 7, and page 9, line 5. The Board also requests the term “physically present” be removed from page Testimony of the Board of Pharmacy H.B. 72, H.D. 2 Page 2 of 2 4, line 10. The Board’s HAR already sufficiently clarifies supervision requirements

- Relating to Pharmacy Hearing Date: Monday, March 10, 2025 at 1:00 p.m. Conference Room: 225 Dear Chair San Buenaventura, Vice Chair Aquino, and Members of the Committee on Health and Human Services: Walgreens submits this testimony in support of H.B. 72, H.D.2, which requires pharmacy technicians to be registered

H.B. 72, H.D.2, which requires pharmacy technicians to be registered with the state. Walgreen Co. (“Walgreens”) operates stores at more than 9,000 locations in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. In Hawaii, Walgreens has 13 stores on the islands of Oahu and Maui. Walgreens supports the

on the islands of Oahu and Maui. Walgreens supports the amendments made in the H.D.1 and H.D.2 to adopt a definition of “auxiliary personnel” for personnel such as cashiers whose responsibilities are purely clerical in nature, to clarify the specific duties of a pharmacy technician, to clarify pharmacist supervision of

duties of a pharmacy technician, to clarify pharmacist supervision of a technician, to establish the specific functions of a pharmacy technician in statute, and to exempt this measure from the requirements of a sunrise analysis. Pharmacy technicians play an important role in the pharmacy setting by handling a range of

role in the pharmacy setting by handling a range of tasks that allow pharmacists to focus on more complex responsibilities like patient consultations and clinical services. For example, pharmacy technicians can assist pharmacists with the preparation, dispensing, and managing of patient medications. Typically, pharmacy technician tasks include filling prescriptions, labeling

patient medications. Typically, pharmacy technician tasks include filling prescriptions, labeling and packaging medications, managing medication inventory, and performing administrative duties such as record-keeping and insurance processing. The 2024 Legislature passed Act 104 that allows, in part, pharmacists, pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns the ability to administer immunizations and vaccinations to

pharmacy interns the ability to administer immunizations and vaccinations to persons three years and older under the direct supervision of a pharmacist. This measure builds upon Act 104 to require that pharmacy technicians are registered by the state. This important measure will bring a regulatory framework to the critical role

measure will bring a regulatory framework to the critical role that pharmacy technicians fill, which Walgreens supports. For these reasons, we ask the committee to pass this bill. members of the Committee, The Hawai'i Pharmacists Association (HPhA) strongly supports HB72 with minor amendments, which will require the registration of pharmacy technicians through the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. Currently, Hawai'i is the only state in the nation without an active and managed registry of practicing pharmacy technicians.

without an active and managed registry of practicing pharmacy technicians. This lack of oversight presents challenges in ensuring consistent training, competency, and accountability within the pharmacy technician workforce. By mandating a registration process, HB72 enhances patient safety, improves workforce standards, and aligns Hawai'i with national best practices. Pharmacy technicians play

and aligns Hawai'i with national best practices. Pharmacy technicians play an essential role in supporting pharmacists and ensuring the safe and efficient delivery of medications. Under the supervision of a pharmacist in the community setting, pharmacy technicians can fill and dispense medications, process insurance claims, and with additional training, administer

dispense medications, process insurance claims, and with additional training, administer vaccinations. In the hospital setting, we rely on pharmacy technicians to support the compounding of intravenous medications and to stock medication cabinets and other medication delivery systems. Pharmacy technicians often have full access to high risk and controlled medications. As

have full access to high risk and controlled medications. As the roles of pharmacy technicians expand across the country, including here in Hawai’i, it’s vital to ensure these essential workers meet a baseline level of competency to ensure patient safety and enhance patient care. Additionally, establishing a technician registry will

and enhance patient care. Additionally, establishing a technician registry will create a vital data repository that enables clear communication of regulatory and practice updates, ensuring the workforce remains aligned with evolving state and federal requirements. HPhA believes that HB72 is a crucial step toward strengthening Hawai'i’s healthcare infrastructure. We feel

a crucial step toward strengthening Hawai'i’s healthcare infrastructure. to serve patients with the highest level of professionalism and safety. list of practicing pharmacy technicians, leaving a significant gap in oversight that can impact patient safety. of training and competency across the profession. HB72 SD1 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 72 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 H.D. 2 STATE OF HAWAII S.D. 1 A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO PHARMACY . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: SECTION 1. Chapter 461, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding a

Chapter 461, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding a new section to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " §461- Registered pharmacy technicians; certificate of registration required. (a) Beginning January 1, 2026, no person shall act as a pharmacy technician without first obtaining a valid certificate of

a pharmacy technician without first obtaining a valid certificate of registration issued by the board pursuant to this section. (b) Each certificate of registration shall be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, upon which the registration shall lapse and a new registration shall be required. (c) The registration

and a new registration shall be required. (c) The registration fee for a pharmacy technician shall be $20. SSCR1082 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1082 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 72 H.D. 2 S.D. 1 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Health and Human Services, to which was referred H.B. No. 72, H.D.

Human Services, to which was referred H.B. No. 72, H.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO PHARMACY," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to: (1) Beginning January 1, 2026, require pharmacy technicians to be registered with and obtain a

require pharmacy technicians to be registered with and obtain a certificate of registration from the Board of Pharmacy; (2) Impose a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians; and (3) Specify that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy

responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Board of Pharmacy; University of Hawai ʻ i System; Walgreen Co.; Hawai ʻ i Pharmacists Association; and five individuals. Your Committee finds that pharmacy technicians are health care

individuals. Your Committee finds that pharmacy technicians are health care professionals working under the supervision of a pharmacist and have an essential role in the daily operation of pharmacies, including the provision of services such as dispensing medications, processing insurance claims, preparing sterile compounds such as intravenous solutions and chemotherapy,

claims, preparing sterile compounds such as intravenous solutions and chemotherapy, and with additional certifications, administering vaccines to patients. Your Committee further finds that Hawaii is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians and that the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for

the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility and trust afforded by the public. This measure requires pharmacy technicians to be registered with the Board of Pharmacy to ensure that pharmacy technicians have the appropriate background and supervision, can receive timely communications and updates

appropriate background and supervision, can receive timely communications and updates regarding relevant practice and regulation changes that impact their work, and are able to access training opportunities as the scope of practice of pharmacy technicians expands nationwide. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Deleting language that would have

amended this measure by: (1) Deleting language that would have required the supervision of a registered pharmacy technician by a registered pharmacist to be "direct" ; (2) Deleting language from the definition of "supervision" that would have required the responsible registered pharmacist to be physically present to oversee a registered

registered pharmacist to be physically present to oversee a registered pharmacy technician or pharmacy technician performing certain acts; (3) Inserting an effective date of December 31, 2050, to encourage further discussion; and (4) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity and consistency. As affirmed by the record of

of clarity and consistency. As affirmed by the record of votes of the members of your Committee on Health and Human Services that is attached to this report, your Committee is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 72, H.D. 2, as amended herein, and recommends that

No. 72, H.D. 2, as amended herein, and recommends that it pass Second Reading in the form attached hereto as H.B. No. 72, H.D. 2, S.D. 1, and be referred to your Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection. Respectfully submitted on behalf of the members of the Committee on Health
on behalf of the members of the Committee on Health and Human Services, ________________________________ JOY A. SAN BUENAVENTURA, Chair

vaccines to patients. As career professionals in the health care workforce, the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility and trust afforded by the public. Thank you for the opportunity to testify in support of HB 72 HD2. e- A¢$ 2‘ D 0”‘ q“

Report Title: Board of Pharmacy; Registered Pharmacy Technicians; Certificate of Registration; Pharmacists-in-charge; Supervision Description: Beginning 1/1/2026, requires pharmacy technicians to be registered with and obtain a certificate of registration from the Board of Pharmacy. Imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge

from the Board of Pharmacy. Imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians. Specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. Effective 12/31/2050. SSCR1082 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1082 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 72 H.D. 2 S.D. 1 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Health and Human Services, to which was referred H.B. No. 72, H.D.

Human Services, to which was referred H.B. No. 72, H.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO PHARMACY," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to: (1) Beginning January 1, 2026, require pharmacy technicians to be registered with and obtain a

require pharmacy technicians to be registered with and obtain a certificate of registration from the Board of Pharmacy; (2) Impose a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations conducted by registered pharmacy technicians; and (3) Specify that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy

responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Board of Pharmacy; University of Hawai ʻ i System; Walgreen Co.; Hawai ʻ i Pharmacists Association; and five individuals. Your Committee finds that pharmacy technicians are health care

individuals. Your Committee finds that pharmacy technicians are health care professionals working under the supervision of a pharmacist and have an essential role in the daily operation of pharmacies, including the provision of services such as dispensing medications, processing insurance claims, preparing sterile compounds such as intravenous solutions and chemotherapy,

claims, preparing sterile compounds such as intravenous solutions and chemotherapy, and with additional certifications, administering vaccines to patients. Your Committee further finds that Hawaii is the only state that does not maintain a list of practicing pharmacy technicians and that the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for

the registration of pharmacy technicians is warranted and appropriate for the level of responsibility and trust afforded by the public. This measure requires pharmacy technicians to be registered with the Board of Pharmacy to ensure that pharmacy technicians have the appropriate background and supervision, can receive timely communications and updates

appropriate background and supervision, can receive timely communications and updates regarding relevant practice and regulation changes that impact their work, and are able to access training opportunities as the scope of practice of pharmacy technicians expands nationwide. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Deleting language that would have

amended this measure by: (1) Deleting language that would have required the supervision of a registered pharmacy technician by a registered pharmacist to be "direct" ; (2) Deleting language from the definition of "supervision" that would have required the responsible registered pharmacist to be physically present to oversee a registered

registered pharmacist to be physically present to oversee a registered pharmacy technician or pharmacy technician performing certain acts; (3) Inserting an effective date of December 31, 2050, to encourage further discussion; and (4) Making technical, nonsubstantive amendments for the purposes of clarity and consistency.
